title: 114_hr3302
content: The "Ensuring Congressional Oversight of Immigration Act" authorizes the Secretary of Homeland Security to exercise authority through U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, with an expiration date of 2 years after enactment unless extended by legislation. Additionally, the Act prohibits the use of funds for certain purposes. No funds, resources, or fees allocated to the Director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services by any Act for any fiscal year can be used to implement policy changes outlined in specific documents, including the memorandum from the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement dated March 2, 2011. The documents related to the removal of aliens include memorandums from the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement dated June 17, 2011, and a U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services policy memorandum dated November 7, 2011. The documents related to immigration enforcement include memorandums from the Principal Legal Advisor of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement dated November 17, 2011, the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement dated April 27, 2012, the Secretary of Homeland Security dated June 15, 2012, and the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement dated June 15, 2012. Enforcement guidance on detainers in federal, state, local, and tribal criminal justice systems, USCIS policy on adjustment of status applications for Visa Waiver Program entrants, DHS memorandums on apprehension, detention, removal of undocumented immigrants, Secure Communities, and prosecutorial discretion for individuals who arrived in the US as children. The Secretary of Homeland Security issued several memorandums on various topics such as expansion of the provisional waiver program, policies supporting high-skilled businesses and workers, families of U.S. armed forces members, and consistency regarding advance parole, all dated November 20, 2014. The memorandums dated November 20 and 21, 2014, address policies to promote access to U.S. citizenship, modernize the immigrant visa system, and integrate immigrants and refugees into welcoming communities.
